name: Qutub Minar
basic_info: Qutub Minar is a UNESCO World Heritage Site located in Delhi and is one of the tallest stone towers in India.
why_built: It was built to mark the beginning of a new rule and to celebrate military victory.
cultural_significance: The monument reflects the early fusion of Indian craftsmanship with Islamic architectural ideas.
symbolism: It symbolizes power, authority, and the architectural ambition of medieval India.
modern_relevance: Today, it reminds people of India’s layered history and cultural coexistence.

name: Taj Mahal
basic_info: The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum and one of the most recognized monuments in the world.
why_built: It was built by Emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal.
cultural_significance: The Taj Mahal represents the artistic peak of Mughal architecture and craftsmanship.
symbolism: It symbolizes eternal love, devotion, and emotional depth beyond power or wealth.
modern_relevance: It continues to inspire people globally as a symbol of love and human emotion.

name: Red Fort
basic_info: The Red Fort is a massive fort complex that once served as the center of Mughal administration.
why_built: It was built to house the Mughal emperors and serve as a political and cultural hub.
cultural_significance: The fort reflects royal life, governance, and artistic traditions of its time.
symbolism: It symbolizes authority, governance, and the rise of organized empires in India.
modern_relevance: Today it stands as a national symbol where India celebrates its independence.

name: Konark Sun Temple
basic_info: The Konark Sun Temple is designed as a giant stone chariot dedicated to the Sun God.
why_built: It was built to honor the Sun God and showcase devotion through architecture.
cultural_significance: The temple reflects ancient India’s scientific understanding of time and astronomy.
symbolism: Its wheels and carvings symbolize the movement of time and cosmic energy.
modern_relevance: It inspires curiosity about ancient Indian knowledge systems and craftsmanship.

name: Brihadeeswarar Temple
basic_info: Brihadeeswarar Temple is a grand Shiva temple built entirely from granite.
why_built: It was constructed to express devotion and the strength of the Chola dynasty.
cultural_significance: The temple represents advanced engineering and spiritual dedication.
symbolism: It symbolizes divine power and the harmony between faith and science.
modern_relevance: It remains a living temple and a pride of South Indian heritage.

name: Golden Temple
basic_info: The Golden Temple is the holiest shrine of Sikhism, known for its serene environment.
why_built: It was built to promote equality, humility, and devotion.
cultural_significance: The temple welcomes people of all religions and backgrounds.
symbolism: It symbolizes unity, selfless service, and inner peace.
modern_relevance: It continues to inspire values of compassion and social harmony.

name: Ajanta Caves
basic_info: Ajanta Caves are a group of rock-cut caves famous for ancient paintings.
why_built: They were created as monasteries and prayer halls for Buddhist monks.
cultural_significance: The caves preserve some of the finest early examples of Indian art.
symbolism: They symbolize meditation, teaching, and spiritual discipline.
modern_relevance: They help us understand ancient storytelling through visual art.

name: Hampi
basic_info: Hampi is the ruined capital of the Vijayanagara Empire.
why_built: It developed as a major political, cultural, and religious center.
cultural_significance: The site reflects a time when art, trade, and governance flourished together.
symbolism: It symbolizes the rise and fall of powerful civilizations.
modern_relevance: Hampi teaches lessons about growth, balance, and impermanence.

name: Sanchi Stupa
basic_info: Sanchi Stupa is one of the oldest stone structures in India.
why_built: It was built to preserve sacred Buddhist relics.
cultural_significance: The site represents early Buddhist philosophy and art.
symbolism: It symbolizes peace, mindfulness, and spiritual growth.
modern_relevance: It remains a center for reflection and inner calm.

name: Gateway of India
basic_info: The Gateway of India is a prominent monument overlooking the Arabian Sea.
why_built: It was built to commemorate the visit of British royalty.
cultural_significance: The monument marks an important colonial chapter in Indian history.
symbolism: It symbolizes transition from colonial rule to independence.
modern_relevance: Today it stands as a cultural landmark and gathering place.
